items.title: Line number reported by test libraries using class decorators is different in Python 3.9 than earlier

milestone.title: v3.2.2
milestone.description: Last planned bug fix release in the RF 3.2.x series.

items.body:
RF 3.1 added support for library source and line numbers (#3507). Testing Python 3.9 it seems that there are small differences how libraries using class decorators are handled in this regard. For example, if we have a library like

```python
@example_decorator
class ExampleLibrary:
    ...
```

earlier the line number of the library would be the line containing `class ExampleLibrary` but with Python 3.9 its the line containing `@example_decorator`. My guess is that [inspect.getsourcelines](https://docs.python.org/3/library/inspect.html#inspect.getsourcelines) that we use internally has changed and nowadays it returns also possible class decorators. That's probably a good idea because it has already earlier worked that way with functions and methods.

We have several ways how to handle this change:

1. Try to follow Python 3.9 semantics also with earlier versions. That's pretty much impossible as this information isn't returned by `getsourcelines` earlier and we don't have any other way to find it.

2. Follow old semantics with Python 3.9 and newer. This is pretty easy as we can simply ignore lines containing decorators before the actual `class` statement. We also already do this with decorated keywords so the behavior would be consistent. Consistency is always good.

3. Do nothing and let different Python versions report different line numbers. Probably not a good idea because behavior would be inconsistent both between Python versions and when looking library and keyword line numbers. Would also require having conditional tests.

Option 2 sounds best to me and will be the way this is fixed.

items.title: XML: `Remove Element(s)` does not work with Python 3.9

milestone.title: v3.2.2
milestone.description: Last planned bug fix release in the RF 3.2.x series.

items.body: The reason is that we use [ElementTree.getiterator](https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/xml.etree.elementtree.html#xml.etree.ElementTree.Element.getiterator) that was deprecated in Python 3.2 and removed in Python 3.9. Easy to fix by using [ElementTree.iter](https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/xml.etree.elementtree.html#xml.etree.ElementTree.Element.iter) with Python 3 and `getiterator` only with Python 2.

items.title: Screenshot: Newer scrot versions don't overwrite images when they should

milestone.title: v3.2.2
milestone.description: Last planned bug fix release in the RF 3.2.x series.

items.body:
The Screenshot library can use different backends for actually taking the screenshot. One of them is [scrot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scrot) and it seems its newer versions have introduced a backwards incompatible change affecting our use case. When giving an output file to scrot like `scrot example.jpg`, it earlier overwrote possible existing files but nowadays it adds a postfix like `example_001.jpg` instead. The Screenshot library already takes care of avoiding overwriting images when needed and overwrites them only when user explicitly wants that behavior but nowadays that doesn't work. In addition to that, it seems that the postfix is added to wrong place if the extension is `.jpeg` resulting with `example.jpeg_001` that scrot itself cannot handle.

I encountered this new behavior on Linux Mint 20 which is based on Ubuntu 20.04 which is based on Debian. Scrot is an old tool that seems to be maintained at https://github.com/resurrecting-open-source-projects/scrot nowadays. Assuming that's the project also used on Mint/Ubuntu/Debian, then the issue requesting this behavior change is resurrecting-open-source-projects/scrot#12 and based on resurrecting-open-source-projects/scrot#30 it seems there are others who aren't entirely happy about it.

items.title: Test filtering (--test) does not work as expected when using "test" search argument along with wildcards
items.body:
Just reporting a weird issue: when using "--test" argument with RF in order to filter the test sequences to execute, just realized that if a search argument such as "test*" is used (which should execute only those test sequences whose name starts with "test"), RF actually executes ALL the tests in the file, no matter how they are named. 

However, this behaviour seems to occur only when specifically using "test", along with a wildcard as the search string, as AFAIK in any other case the filtering behaves as expected.

Included as an attachment a very simple example RF test file, containing two test cases, named "case_1" and "case_2" (which actually do nothing). The following situations occur:
`robot --test "case_1" test_filter.robot`
Executes only "case_1" test - **OK**
`robot --test "case*" test_filter.robot`
Executes both "case_1" and "case_2" - **OK**
`robot --test "test" test_filter.robot`
Gives an error, as no test case is named "test" - **OK**
`robot --test "test*" test_filter.robot`
Executes both "case_1" and "case_2" tests, even if none of them has "test" in its name - **WRONG**

[test_filter.robot.txt](https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/files/4918199/test_filter.robot.txt)

Tested on Windows 10, using RF v3.2.1 on Python 3.7.3 (win32 edition).

items.title: Enum conversion should work with normalized names

labels.name: acknowledge
labels.description: To be acknowledged in release notes

milestone.title: v3.2.2
milestone.description: Last planned bug fix release in the RF 3.2.x series.

items.body:
We are using a lot of enums in Browser Library and would like to have the automatic conversion from strings in RF to enum members in Python being able to match members based on a normalized string.

Because members of enums can not contains spaces, like method names in python, but spaces are typically quite common in RobotFramework we want to be able to allow spaces in member names.
Same with case sensitivity. 
Case sensitivity with values is very rare.

Lets assume we have the following enum:
```python
AssertionOperator = Enum(
    "AssertionOperator",
    {
        "noassertion": "NO_ASSERTION",
        "NO_ASSERTION": "NO_ASSERTION",
        "equal": "==",
        "==": "==",
        "shouldbe": "==",
        "inequal": "!=",
        "!=": "!=",
        "shouldnotbe": "!=",
        "lessthan": "<",
        "<": "<",
        "greaterthan": ">",
        ">": ">",
        "<=": "<=",
        ">=": ">=",
        "contains": "*=",
        "*=": "*=",
        "starts": "^=",
        "^=": "^=",
        "shouldstartwith": "^=",
        "ends": "$=",
        "shouldendwith": "$=",
        "$=": "$=",
        "matches": "$",
        "validate": "validate",
        "then": "then",
    },
)
```

The values in robot `shouldnotbe`, `Should Not Be` and `should_not_be` etc all match to the member `shouldnotbe`

When documenting the enum in libdoc it should also document the "robotic" name `Should Not Be`

This is related to #3607 but imho with a higher priority.

items.title: Merge libdoc output
items.body:
Hey,

_this is more or less a feature request, I guess._

We are faced to the problem that we have spreaded keywords over a (custom python) robot library (providing basic keywords) and keywords in robot resource files (using the basic keywords from the robot library). So this keywords from lib and keywords from resource files belongs conceptional together and thus might be inside **one html** output of libdoc. (Emphasize by: The library is included by the resource file. The test includes the resource file only.)

Libdoc is will create one html/xml per

* Library
* Resource file

Anyway issue https://github.com/robotframework/MavenPlugin/issues/28 looks it has the same or a similar intention. But the fix addresses Maven (java world only).

**I currently have several ideas in mind to fix**

1. Extending `libdoc` doing this job (harvesting several input files into one xml/html. The input parameter allow e.g. a path or some regular expression matching input files rather then one input file.)
2. Extending `rebot` to merge libdoc xml files.
3. Simply writing a small script using libdoc as module or merging the xml outputs into one xml file.

**For 1:**

The idea is to extent the CLI of libdoc, currenlty [supporting two arguments for writing output](https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/5dc9affd4aee31703a58ad105ed49579b1ca7067/src/robot/libdoc.py#L155) only.

A technical solution can be this way: Extent `class LibdocModelWriter` to support a list of `LibraryDocumentation`, thus [`JsonConverter` constructs a compound/join list of keywords](https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/5dc9affd4aee31703a58ad105ed49579b1ca7067/src/robot/libdocpkg/htmlwriter.py#L40) (and joined list of doc summary) from every resource specfied in CLI _within one json object_.

**For 2:**

I thought maybe rebot can do that. It has [`--merge`](https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/5dc9affd4aee31703a58ad105ed49579b1ca7067/src/robot/rebot.py#L88)  parameter. From scratch that jobs end up with a message like:  

```
rebot --merge docs/MyLib.xml docs/resources/mylibsresource1.resource.xml --outputfile docs/MyLibFramework.xml

[ERROR ] Reading XML source 'docs/MyLib.xml' failed: Incompatible XML element 'keywordspec'.
```

So its not desigend for libdoc xml's. 

Idea to to fix: [more handlers](https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/src/robot/result/xmlelementhandlers.py) needs to be implemented.

**For 3**

Looks like [this post](https://github.com/robotframework/MavenPlugin/issues/28#issuecomment-304668150) had the similar idea ;) 

What do you think about this plans? Does one maybe overlaps with some roadmap? Is one preferred over the other (especially 1 vs 2)?

items.body: Firefox has a bug handling element widths when they use `::first-letter`. As a result Libdoc's keyword shortcuts were always messed up until we added a workaround (#3456) in RF 3.2. items.title: Set logging level for a certain library
items.body:
I'm importing custom library in my test based on some other python modules which are using python `logging`. In certain situations python `logging` inside python packages emits `ERROR` message which I would like to disable. The problem is I've tried different ways but all of them are not working:

1. Set log level inside custom library for imported python module
    ```python
    imported_logger = logging.getLogger('<name of imported python module>')
    imported_logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)
    ```

items.title: Execution can crash if `stdin` is closed
items.body:
After upgrading from `3.1.2` to `3.2.` some of our code stopped working with peculiar exception:

```
...
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/robot/__init__.py in <module>
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/robot/rebot.py in <module>
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/robot/conf/__init__.py in <module>
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/robot/conf/settings.py in <module>
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/robot/output/__init__.py in <module>
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/robot/output/output.py in <module>
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/robot/output/pyloggingconf.py in <module>
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/robot/utils/__init__.py in <module>
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/robot/utils/argumentparser.py in <module>
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/robot/utils/encoding.py in <module>
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/robot/utils/encodingsniffer.py in get_console_encoding()
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/robot/utils/encodingsniffer.py in _get_encoding()
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/robot/utils/encodingsniffer.py in _get_stream_output_encoding()
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/robot/utils/compat.py in isatty()
ValueError: I/O operation on closed file
```

It looks like Robot now calls `isatty()` at `sys.__stdin__` object. That leads to aforementioned exception. MWE from JupyterLab in case someone wants to double-check:

```python
def process():
    import sys; sys.__stdin__.isatty()

import dask.distributed
with dask.distributed.Client("[REDACTED]") as executor:
    next(dask.distributed.as_completed([executor.submit(process)])).result()
```

There are lots of moving parts in our setup, so in case you have additional questions (like Dask version, JupyterLab version), please ask.

items.title: Regression with keywords implemented as methods with wrapping decorator
items.body:
--------------

_This regression in RF 3.2 affects at least AppiumLibrary (#3559) and FakerLibrary (#3560)._

--------------

If a keyword is implemented as a method in a class and the method is decorated with a "wrapping decorator", argument detection doesn't work correctly. A "wrapping decorator" is a decorator that sets the `__wrapped__` attribute using [functools.wraps](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functools.html#functools.wraps) or otherwise.

The following is enough to reproduce the problem. Running the test fails because Robot Framework incorrectly things that `Keyword` requires one argument.

```python
from functools import wraps


def decorator(func):
    @wraps(func)
    def wrapper(*args, **kws):
        return func(*args, **kws)
    return wrapper


class ExampleLibrary:

    @decorator
    def keyword(self):
        pass
```

```robotframework
*** Settings ***
Library          ExampleLibrary.py

*** Test Cases ***
Example
    Keyword
```

Prior to Robot Framework 3.2 arguments of wrapped methods like the above were not seen at all and Robot just blindly accepted all arguments. This was changed by #3027 that added [inspect.unwrap](https://docs.python.org/3/library/inspect.html#inspect.unwrap) to our argument resolving logic. The PR implementing that feature didn't actually yet cause this issue because it used code like `inspect.getfullargspec(inspect.unwrap))` which is fine. Unfortunately the PR only added tests for unwrapping functions, not methods, so when the code was changed later this bug wasn't detected.

This was broken as part of refactoring in fa5ad5153f8ea77e70b4c07a1561810aac78f169 when code like `hander = inspect.unwrap(hander)` was introduced because it affected also `inspect.ismethod(hander)` call a bit later. As the result the handler wasn't detected to be a method and the `self` argument wasn't dropped from the argument list.

items.title: Libdoc spec files: Change type to upper case  `LIBRARY` and `RESOURCE`
items.body:
Currently the type is either `library` or `resource`. Using upper case `LIBRARY` and `RESOURCE` would be consistent with the doc format (`ROBOT`, `HTML`, ...) and newly changed scope (`GLOBAL`, `SUITE`, ...) (#3532).

The change is backwards incompatible but ought to be easy to handle by external tools. The actual value is the same so tools can just upper or lower case the value when they read it.

items.title: Libdoc spec files: Change scope to use values `GLOBAL`, `SUITE` and `TEST` consistently
items.body:
The current situation is this:
- With resource files scope is an empty string.
- With libraries scope is `global`, `test suite`, or `test case`.

The plan for the future:
- With resource files scope is `GLOBAL`.
- With libraries scope is `GLOBAL`, `SUITE`, or `TEST`. This change is highly related to #3531 in the implementation level.

We can easily make this change in backward compatible manner by updating only the value of the new `scope` attribute. The `scope` element that was deprecated by #3522 can still  get the old values.

items.title: Allow using `"SUITE"` and `"TEST"` as library scope values
items.body:
Currently the values to be used when defining library scope using the `ROBOT_LIBRARY_SCOPE` attribute are `GLOBAL`, `TEST SUITE` and `TEST CASE`. The default is `TEST CASE` and it is used also if the given value is not recognized. I propose supporting also `SUITE` instead of `TEST SUITE` and `TEST` instead of `TEST CASE` for the following reasons:

- In the RPA usage it's nicer to be able to use value `TEST SUITE` instead of `SUITE`. 
- There's typically no need to use value `TEST CASE` as it's the default, but if an explicit value is needed `TEST` is consistent with `SUITE`. Not needing spaces with any of these values is a minor plus as well.
- Although the `TEST` value is not that good in the RPA world, it doesn't matter much because unrecognized values are anyway mapped to the test case scope internally and thus `TASK` works fine as an explicit scope.

items.title: Libdoc specs: Change generation time to be valid `xsd:dateTime`
items.body:
The generation time in Libdoc spec files (`generated` attribute) is currently in format `YYYYMMDD hh:mm:ss`. While creating a schema for spec files (#3520), we noticed that using a format that is valid [xsd:dateTime](http://www.datypic.com/sc/xsd/t-xsd_dateTime.html) would be better.

~I propose we switch to format `YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss`. There might be small benefits for including the time zone, but our `get_timestamp` utility doesn't support adding the timezone and in my opinion updating it isn't worth the effort. Adding it can still be considered, though.~

Scrap the above, we naturally can use the [datetime](https://docs.python.org/3/library/datetime.html) module for this purpose. I propose we use time in UTC and use format `2020-03-31T09:14:52Z`. I'd kind of like to use the real timezone instead of `Z`, but that doesn't seem to be easy to implement with Python 2. Using UTC makes also comparing values easier (string comparison is enough) and avoids problems with DST altogether. We can also get this format easily:

```python
>>> from datetime import datetime
>>> datetime.utcnow().replace(microsecond=0).isoformat() + 'Z'
'2020-03-31T09:20:40Z'
```

This is backwards incompatible change but I doubt the generation time is widely used.

items.title: Add spec version to Libdoc spec files
items.body:
We are making several changes to Libdoc spec file elements and attributes (#3522, #3507, #3498) in RF 3.2 and are also going to create a schema for them (#3520). To make it easier for external tools to handle future changes, we should add the spec version to the spec files as well.

My thinking is that we should add `specversion` attribute to the top level `keywordspec` element. The value should be a positive integer that is incremented between RF versions when changes are made. The version with RF 3.2 should be `2`.

items.title: Libdoc spec files: Change `scope` and `namedargs` to attributes
items.body:
Currently Libdoc spec files contain `namedargs` element with value `yes/no` and `scope` element with whatever scope the library uses. Neither of them can contain multiline values and they would work better as library attributes. This also allows changing `namedargs` to be Boolean with `true/false`. 

Initially the idea was to change the `namedags` value from `yes/no` to `true/false` (#3521) but that works better if `namedargs` is an attribute, not an element. Doing it this way also avoids backwards compatibility issues. There's no good reason to leave `scope` to be an element so that can be changed at the same time.

Spec files contain also `version` element, but we don't validate its value so it can be multiline. Better to leave it as an element.

items.title: Libdoc spec files: Change value of `namedargs` from `yes/no` to `true/false`
items.body:
We are going to create a schema for Libdoc spec files. XSD schema allows specifying that an attribute is a Boolean and then its values are limited to `true/false` and `1/0`. We should change Libdocs's `namedargs` attribute to use `true/false` instead of `yes/no` that it currently uses.

This isn't strictly necessary in order to be able to create a schema but certainly makes a lot of sense. The change also removes inconsistency between `namedargs` and the recently introduced `deprecated` that uses `true/false` (#3498).

The change itself is a trivial change but unfortunately backwards incompatible. In my opinion it's still OK before RF 3.2, even though we very close to the first release candidate. It is unlikely that many external tools use this attribute in the first place, and those who do can be easily updated to handle both `true/false` and `yes/no`.

items.body: Libdoc spec files don't have official schema definition. Now that they've got new attributes `deprecated` (#3498) as well as `source` and `lineno` (#3507) that creating a schema gets even more important.

items.title: FOR LOOP on EMPTY LIST stopped working in RIDE 1.7.4.1 with Robotframework 3.0.4
Dynamic API: Add new `get_keyword_source` method
items.body:
This is needed to make it possible to add source information to Libdoc spec files (#3507) as well as to Libdoc's model objects (#3448). External tools like editors can then use this information to implement "go to definition" functionality.

This method needs to be able to return both the path to the source file and the line number, and we need to decide which format to use. Good alternatives include a tuple `(source, lineno)` as well as a string `source:lineno`. Not sure why, but I like the latter approach better.

items.title: Dynamic API: Support returning real default values from `get_keyword_arguments`
items.body:
Currently `get_keyword_arguments` in the dynamic library API returns the argument specification as a list of strings like `['mandatory', 'optional=default', '**kws']`. This works fine otherwise, but because all items in the spec are strings, something like `['x=1', 'y=None', 'z=True']` is interpreted so that default values `1`, `None` and `True` are all strings. This isn't typically a big problem because default values are mainly used for validation argument counts and for documentation purposes, but there are two cases where Robot Framework not getting the real default values causes issues:

1. Type information got from default values is used for automatic argument conversion starting from RF 3.1 (#2932). This is especially useful with common default values `None`, `True` and `False`, and obviously doesn't currently work at all with dynamic libraries. This is a problem, for example, for the SeleniumLibrary.

2. If the `run_keyword` method doesn't accept `kwargs` and the named argument syntax is used so that optional arguments are skipped, the given default values are passed to the executed keyword as part of `args`. This is a pretty rare situation (it was more common before #2930) and probably wouldn't alone be worth changes.

items.title: Consider reading PIPE buffer to avoid deadlock
items.body:
When subprocess PIPE buffers run out it will usually leads to a blocked write, which deadlocks the subprocess trying to write and robot waiting for the process (if e.g. started with `Run Process`).  

To avoid this it would be nice if, while [waiting for the subprocess to complete](https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/e428e47c821808316e47cc654e3333bf96ad46c2/src/robot/libraries/Process.py#L475), robot use [`communicate()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html#subprocess.Popen.communicate) or maybe the [context manager](https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html#popen-constructor):
```py
with Popen(["ifconfig"], stdout=PIPE) as proc:
    log.write(proc.stdout.read())
```
to copy from PIPE to local buffer.

Although this is a known issue. Here's a small test case that blocks on my CentOS 7.4 (`3.10.0-957.21.3.el7.x86_64 #1 SMP Tue Jun 18 16:35:19 UTC 2019 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux`) using `Robot Framework 3.1.1 (Python 3.5.3 on linux)`. Results may of course vary depending on the system buffer sizes. On mine the PIPE buffer appears to be 65536 bytes.
```robot
*** Settings ***
Library  Process

*** Test Cases ***

Write Ok

        Run Process  dd   if\=/dev/zero  of\=/dev/stdout  bs\=1  count\=65536

Write Blocks

        Run Process  dd   if\=/dev/zero  of\=/dev/stdout  bs\=1  count\=65537
```

items.title: Libdoc could better handle keywords deprecation info
items.body:
When keyword is deprecated it's documentation needs to start from `*DEPRECATED*`. This is useful information for IDEs because it can emit a warning for usages of such keywords or it can flag those keywords in the GUI parts which somehow displays deprecated keyword. In the end this is useful for users to be able to quickly spot which part of their codebase became deprecated thus allowing cleaning the code earlier and be ready for newer releases.

Currently this information in XML library specification file is not written anywhere - the tools need to read the documentation text to look for a `*DEPRECATED*` flag. It would be better not to read it but have such information explicitely written in the specification file for example by having `<deprecated>true</deprecated>` element under `<kw>` .

It is also worth considering having such element required (also written when `<deprecated>false</deprecated>`) because this would allow the tools to handle both ways during transition period when both formats would be supported. Without it the tool would have to look anyway into the documentation text if `*DEPRECATED*` is there because not having `<deprecated>` could mean that specification file was generated with RF <3.2 or that it was generated with 3.2+ but it is not deprecated hence no element was written.

This issue is reported after discussion here: https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/issues/3491#issuecomment-596484623

items.title: FOR IN ZIP and FOR IN ENUMERATE enhancements
items.body:
While refactoring FOR loop code to make it easier to implement `&{dict}` iteration (#3485) I noticed some limitations in the current FOR IN ZIP and FOR IN ENUMERATE loops originally added by #1952.

Problems related to FOR IN ZIP are caused by the fact that nowadays these loops require having the same number of variables and values like in:

```
FOR    ${x}    ${y}    IN ZIP    ${LIST 1}    ${LIST 2}
    # ...
END
```

This means that it isn't possible to get lists to iterate over from a list variable like this:

```
FOR    ${x}    ${y}    IN ZIP    @{LISTS}
    # ...
END
```

Another problem is that it isn't possible to use just one loop variable that would get items from all lists like:

```
FOR    ${items}    IN ZIP    ${LIST 1}    ${LIST 2}
    # ...
END
```

With FOR IN ENUMERATE loops the problem is similar to the latter issue with FOR IN ZIP. It isn't possible to have just one FOR IN ENUMERATE loop variable that gets both the index and the item.

```
FOR    ${index and item}    IN ENUMERATE    a    b    c    d    e
    # ...
END
```

None of limitations are big but especially being able to use list variables with FOR IN ZIP loops could sometimes be handy. Fixing the problems while otherwise cleaning up the code is easy.

items.title: Libdoc: Support `*.libspec` extension when reading library information from spec files
items.body:
Libdoc allows creating XML files with information about a certain library:

    $ python -m robot.libdoc BuiltIn BuiltIn.xml

When using the `--format` option, it is possible to use also other extensions than `*.xml`:

    $ python -m robot.libdoc --format xml BuiltIn BuiltIn.libspec

Having a custom extension for these spec files is handy, but unfortunately Libdoc itself cannot read information from them anymore as it only supports the `*.xml` extension:

    $ python -m robot.libdoc BuiltIn.xml version
    3.2b2

    $ python -m robot.libdoc BuiltIn.libspec version
    Importing test library '/path/BuiltIn.libspec' failed: Not a valid file or directory to import.

The problem is that internally Libdoc considers only `*.xml` files to be spec files and tries to import others as libraries or resource files. This also affects Libdoc's public API (#3448) possibly used by the LSP project (robocorp/robotframework-lsp#20).

We could enhance Libdoc to auto-detect the type of the given argument by looking at what it contains, but that would be somewhat complicated and also error prone. It's a lot easier if we just agree on an explicit extension to use. The `*.libspec` extension is apparently already used by the RED editor and we should just standardize that. It would basically mean these changes:

1. Change Libdoc to consider `*.libspec` files as spec files when reading information.
2. Automatically use XML format when the output file extension is `*.libspec` like we do if the extension is `*.xml`.
3. We could also consider specifying this so that `*.libspec` files should use `XML:HTML` format (#3301) i.e. have the library and keyword docs converted to HTML.

items.title: Variable containing `=` in its name should not initiate named argument syntax
items.body:
When Robot Framework detects is the named argument syntax (`name=value`) used in keyword calls or in the Variables section when defining `&{dict}` variables, it tries to find the first un-escaped equal sign and splits the value from there. This logic currently has a small bug that `=` is also searched inside variable names. For example, this causes and error nowadays:

```
*** Variables ***
&{DICT}          ${{'='}}=value
```

This isn't too severe because `=` is pretty rare in variable names in general and because such syntax is fine in the value part of the `name=value` syntax.

If we implement dictionary iteration with FOR loops (#3485), it gets somewhat more likely that this bug causes concrete problems.  In fact, two of our own acceptance tests failed due to that with a prototype implementation of dict iteration. Better to fix this issue now.

items.title: Allow to import variables with different namespace
items.body:
Recently I've discovered neat RF feature: import variables from yaml file. Example:

```
*** Settings ****
Variables  my_vars.yaml
```

For my_vars.yaml file:
```
some_var: 1    
some_dict_var:    
    key: value    
```

Variables import that way will be directly accessible in Robot. I would like to be able to assign some 'namespace' to them though - same as I can do it with libraries. Of course I can do this:

```
my_namespace:    
    some_var: 1    
    some_dict_var:    
         key: value    
```

But it's not as flexible - I can't assign two 'namespaces' to one file. 
Proposal:

```
**** Settings ***    
Variables  my_vars.yaml  AS  some_mapping    
```
This will get me variable ${some_mapping} (dict like) that will contain all variables inside file. 

By looking at source code here https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/blob/master/src/robot/variables/filesetter.py#L63 I see that it's enough to change following lines to somehow like (that's only some quick dirty code, it needs polishing etc):

```
    def import_variables(self, path, args=None):    
        variables = self._import(path)    
        yaml_variables = [('${%s}' % name, self._dot_dict(value))    
                for name, value in variables]    
        if not args:    
            return yaml_variables    
        if (len(args) != 2) or (args[0].lower() != 'as'):    
             raise DataError('YAML variable files do not accept arguments.')    
        return  ('${%s}'  % args[1], yaml_variables)    
```

items.title: BuiltIn: Consistent argument names to `Should Contain X Times` and `Get Count`
items.body:
Currently these keyword accepts arguments `item1` and `item2` while e.g. `Should Contain` accepts `container` and `item`. We should use the latter ones also with  `Should Contain X Times` and `Get Count` because a) they are much better named and b) consistency is good.

This change is backwards incompatible, but only if someone has used these arguments using the named argument syntax like `item1=example    item2=ex`. That ought to be so rare that this change ought to be fine in a major version like RF 3.2.

items.title: Native `&{dict}` iteration with FOR loops
items.body:
It is possible to extract the keys and values in a python for loop. This is not possible in Robot Framework (or we need to use a more complicated strategy to obtain the same result).

In python we can do:
```python
dict = { 'a':'one', 'b':'two'}
for key, value in dict.items():
    print(key, value)
```
It is requested to implement:
```robot
&{dict}=  Create Dictionary  a=one  b=two
FOR    ${key}    ${value}    IN    &{dict}
  LOG  ${key} ${value}
END
```

items.title: String: Rename `convert_to_uppercase` to `convert_to_upper_case` (and same with `lower`)
items.body:
We are going to add `Convert To Title Case` (#2706) and because "title case" works so much better than "titlecase" it will be implemented by method `convert_to_title_case`. Although "uppercase" and "lowercase" are OK alternatives to "upper case" and "lower case", it's better for consistency reasons to rename `convert_to_uppercase` and  `convert_to_lowercase` to `convert_to_upper_case` and `convert_to_lower_case`, respectively.

Because Robot's keyword matching logic is space and underscore insensitive, this change doesn't affect anyone using these keywords normally. Both `Convert To Uppercase` and `Convert To Upper Case` work now and will work also in the future. The change affects those using these methods programmatically like `String().convert_to_uppercase('hello')`, but because such usage makes absolutely no sense compared to simple `'hello'.upper()`, I don't think that's a real problem even this late in the RF 3.2 release cycle.

items.title: Libdoc: Not possible to link to Tags section
items.body: Libdoc allows linking to custom sections (#1247) as well as to automatically created Shortcuts, Keywords and Importing sections. If any keyword has tags, there's also Tags section but linking to it isn't possible. This affects also automatically creating table of contents (#3280).

items.title: Add a section "Test Execution Messages" at the top of the report
items.body:
Currently, when I want to display important messages of test executions, I use the log level "warning", so that, the messages are displayed in a dedicaced frame "Test Execution Errors" and easily visible.

It works, but it is not really correct because these messages are not really warnings messages.

It could be great to have another frame, named like "Test Execution messages" where all the Log with a specific level are displayed. 
For example log level "MESSAGE".

Mockup : 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/56358900/74454802-b5be0400-4e84-11ea-9e7f-acb084f8a1da.png)

items.title: Mouse Over does not work on IE11 (windows10)
items.body:
I have many test cases which includes Mouse Over and are failing repeatedly in IE. I am using Selenium2Library. This works fine on Firefox and Chrome. 
I can see that similar issue is been raised for SeleniumLibrary but according to closing comment, the issue should have been disappeared but it's still there.

items.title: Better reporting if using valid setting is used in wrong context
items.body: Currently if, for example, `Test Template` is used in a resource file or in a suite initialization file the resulting error is something like `Invalid setting 'Test Template'.`. This is a bit confusing because `Test Template` is a valid setting, it's just used in a wrong context. A better error would be something like `Setting 'Test Template' is not allowed in resource file.`. Totally invalid settings should be reported as earlier.

items.title: Add support for svg image links in documentation

labels.name: acknowledge
labels.description: To be acknowledged in release notes

items.body:
There's a feature in documentation fields where it converts image links to img tags, e.g. [mypic.jpg|Title] -> <img src="mypic.jpg" title="Title"/>. It'd be nice if it supported svg files.

Related to PR: #3462
